description.text: Strimmer blade for Bosch ART23, STL file and ProDESKTOP 8 original file. These are £8 for 20 in B&Q, I thought it looked like a straightforward make with my K8200 and it is. I have used 3mm clear PLA extruded at 180c. The blades seem to work just as well as the originals and are a fraction of the cost. I have just made 2 more in the time it has taken to upload these to Thingiverse. I admit I should have drawn it laying flat so it will need to be rotated 90 degrees and make sure that the flat side is face down before printing (both side are different).

Gaming terrain, made of seperate components so I can design alternate versions of each component as I see fit.  
Update 1: New wall and cap files added, with file names ending in "1a_6-column" for a more open design.  
Update 2: Added a new base_1a with a smaller center circle, and a fountain for it.  
Update 3: Added pedestals to fit the center of base_1a. Two have round recesses for standard 25mm game miniature bases, and two are designed to fit Pocket-Tactics structures such as the "Crystal Palace" piece from thingiverse.com/thing:53543 or the "Tower of Sorcery" from thingiverse.com/thing:50096 designed by dutchmogul.  
Update 4: Added alternate slender columns and cap option, and a bench seat option.

The complete model is just for illustration. You need to print the base, the walls, the colums, and the cap. The sockets for part connections are designed with a small clearance, so no filing should be necessary to make everything fit.
Feedback welcome.

Update: followed by modular box system:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:506288 my latest creation- an exposure frame for pcb 60x100mm
It will give you a techno looking robust picture frame as well. The latest and the greatest thing in a series of frames I designed the last days.
I'v started with these things:
  • modded the thing:498613
  • made http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:501257
  • made http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:502919
  • made http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:501886
    • The bottom part holds one pcb 60x100x1.75mm and a sheet of transparent paper or acrylic film with the layout you have printed out.
    The top part holds a thin glass plate.
    The design allows for easy milling the parts from 8-10mm thick metal sheet or hard plastics blocks. The files:
    newest fixed and streamlined top part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:505896
    new bottom part with cave where springily soft material goes in
    bottom part (pcb-holder)
    top part (glas-holder) Sketch drawn with very tight tolerances. It was a long way from modding other poeples stuff to this stage: design your own thing and make some progress one step after the other. Learn from failure, improve functionality, design, finish.
    Go through the iterations.
    Eventually make the final design.
    Head over to the next thing.
    Create, make, share things. I'm so excited. huh!

Sketches are drawn with very tight tolerances.
Update: the top parts window has an offset of 1mm, this will be fixed soon :DONE

Things you should know:
glass : 65mm x 110mm x 2mm (more thickness is ok, only limited by the screws length)
glass for top frame version2: 66mm x 105mm x 2mm
pcb: 60 x 100 mm
your sketch: 65 x 110mm
Don't exxeed these sizes.
.
Print first, measure the real dimension twice, cut once.
Be accurat with the pcb and the sheet as much as possible.
However have the glass cut to size smaler by 0.2mm should be ok.
.
I have printed using PLA (orange from Kiboplast, I recommend this heartly , very good stuff)
The bag holding the pcb is in average 60.02mm wide.
The calculated size is 60.0mm. I'm very pleased with this result.
To compensate plastics shrinking (ABS) add some percentages in your slicer programm settings in (2-5 percent as usual).
Attention please: look at the things size not the feed amount!
if any increase the x-y-axis dimensions only
.
How to use this thing:
Look at the vey first picture in the galery, please!
Better look at my video on Youtube :
assembling the frame http://shortlinks.de/5iam
If it won't work got to Youtube, find user "Maki Box" , select video"pcb exposer frame"
.
put your things together in this order:
into the bottom frame
-the soft matte (?) or slice of a sponge
-the pcb clad
-the fotofilm
.
put the glas into the top frame .
This may be the tricky part. You have find out how to assemble the pieces together without falling off.
Take some adhesive?
Fasten the glas temporarily with the top frame using some drops of superfast glue (cyanacrylat based).
.
like with a usual box with lid , the topframe goes onto the bottomframe
fasten the screws and do the exposure
screw the parts together with screws 3mm.
The poor imperial things user will have to do some math;-).
.
But I can help you out: 3mm equals 0.012 inch.
.
If you have trouble aligning or stacking the things together:
print your pcb pattern with index marker and circles on a sheet / flim sized the same or bigger than the frames dimension
cut out or stamp out small holes 3mm wide centered with the passmarks
use the screwholes for alignment
hole (centre) distances: 70mm x 115mm
.
If there is some interist I could make some modifications:
  • a top part without sunken holes (more rigid)
  • bottom part without the badge for the pattern sheet / -foil.
    -wider bottom part with slide-in rails for easy insert of your pcb- pattern you have sealed in selfmade bags , I'm not sure about this- it may bow the film's edge areas when pushed by the glass plate toward the pcb
    .
    Let me know.

remixed_from.author: Freakazoid
remixed_from.title: Flash Drive Cryptex - Combination Lock for your data

description.text:
look in instructions for make details. this was remixed to hopefully be a slightly better test. the original post was: This is still a work-in-progress. It does work, but there are still some things that need improvement. I would be happy to hear your ideas and thoughts.
Here are the points I'll try to improve in the future:
  • The design of the flashdrive case (The fact that is has to be glued and also that I had to sand it to fit into the jacket)
  • The connection between cover and jacket (again I'm no fan of glueing)
  • The numbers on the rings (The partially didn't come out right, at least not on my printer)

Here are the parts you'll have to print:
  • USBCaseA.stl
  • USBCaseB.stl
  • Cover.stl
  • Jacket.stl
  • Spacer.stl (3x)
  • RingX (4x consisting of your desired combination)
    For the case you'll have to disassemble your flashdrive and fit the circuit into the two halfs of. I printed them with support material. Depending on your drive you might have to carve it into place a little bit, because I designed it for the drive I had laying around.
    Now glue the two halfes and the drive together. For ABS this shouldn't be a problem. If your using PLA (like me) I recommend you using some slow-hardening epoxy glue. Worked just fine for me.
    Stick your printed number rings on the jacket. They must be separated by the three spacer parts, otherwise the cryptex won't lock. In the end you'l have to glue the Cover to the jacket, so the rings can not come off. Now you should be ready to go. Enjoy!
    !!!New customizable rings!!!
    There is a new OpenSCAD script I wrote. Now you're able to customize your rings. With this you can:
  • Choose the unlocking position for your rings
  • Change the symbols (Letters, numbers special signs)
    Just download the zip-file, open the CustomizableRingRev1.scad, type in your parameters, press F6 to compile and finally go to "Design > Export as STL..."

I made this derivative from JJShortcut's files ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415 ), but the original gears were giving me some grief, so after the second micro-servo broke I redesigned the thing with involuted gears. Operation should be much smoother now.

This is designed to be routed with a 1.5 mm straight cutter. Do not use tool diameter compensation on the gears, they have been rescaled and modified taking into account the tool radius. Do use tool diameter compensation on the other parts. Use 6 M2x16 bolts to fasten the gears to the arms, the counterbored side of the gears holds the m2 screwcaps and should be placed against the plate, arms on the other side. Otherwise assembles just like previously described.

author: Lightning87

description.text:
THIS HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY PRINTED
This is my version of a Flame Gun from Logan's Run.
It has a spring loaded trigger and the cap on the back can be removeable. I've left room for those of you that may want to add electoronics. There is room in the back of the barrel to insert batteries or electronics and easily access them by popping off the back cap. There is also room in the handle below the trigger although that space can ony be accessed during assembly. I've included some printed screw heads for those that want it completely 3D printed but they are small and hard to print. I also included a toggle switch that can be printed or you can drill into the print and mount a real toggle. With this gun you can take out all the runners you ever dreamed of. Good luck and happy hunting!

Parts have been saved out individually for easier printing. I ganged the smaller parts to help keep them from warping or melting by keeping the print head busy jumping between the parts.
Please note the side plate has a peg for the trigger which matches up with a hole in the trigger. This peg tends to break. I recommend replacing it with a metal peg or just ignoring it. The trigger works well without being pegged at all.

remixed_from.author: Doogiekr
remixed_from.title: Right and Left Minimalistic Mk8 replacement - Modded

description.text: A modded version of the MK8 extruder upgrade ready for the Makerbot Replicator 2. It replaces the notorious delrin plunger with a ball bearing. Extruder reliability is increased and it actually fits perfectly in the Rep2.

What you get: Mounting & Lever part ready to fit the Rep2 filament stepper. My Printing settings: I printed with 2 Shells at 100% Infill at 0.2mm layers. What you'll need:
  • a 623 bearing (3mmx10mmx4mm)
  • a 10mm M3 grub screw
  • a 20mm M3 flat head screw (shortened mine to 18mm)
  • a 10mm m3 flat head screw (shortened mine to 8mm)

  • 3 wire springs from 2 foldback clips (I used 20mm ALCO foldback clips)

  • a sharp knife, some rasps, manual skills and a bit of patience.

title: Plastruder MK4 Replacement Parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Has your plastruder ever self-destructed? Has the filament guide middle cracked? Behold the Replacement Parts! These are parts that often break in the plastruder. Right now I only have filament guide middle but more are to come. Or you can ask for any lasercut part in the plastruder and I can whip you up a replacement part design. If you would like the source, just ask and I will upload. I use Sketchup. NOTE: This is still untested. Please let me know if this works or if I have to scale it differently. Darn Sketchup imports DXFs at a ridiculous scale and I have to experiment to get it the right size. UPDATE
If you have downloaded the Filament Guide Middle or Insulator Retainer before 12/6/2010, then you will need to redownload. New versions uploaded that are much more dimensionally correct.
Temporarily fix your plastruder (if possible) and print (or ask a friend to print one). Then simply drop in your replacement. Please provide feedback if it doesn't work like the lasercut version.

title: Bicycle Lamp Mount (for Busch & Müller LUMOTEC IQ Cyo senso plus)

description.text:
The "Busch & Müller LUMOTEC IQ Cyo sense plus" is a quite good and expensive bicycle LED lamp. If you don't want to throw it away just because its mount is broken: my 3D printed mount will help :-).
I also add the Rhino File (.3dm) and an export from Rhino for AutoCad (.dwg), so you maybe can make it fit for other lamps too.

I print this with an infill of 50% to make it quite stable.  
One print before I had only used 30% and it broke, when the bike fall down once....

author: KlausBreuer

description.text:
The original model was pretty neat, but I wanted a little more detail, and I wanted it able to be printed without additional support so I tweaked it up a bit.
It prints really well and can be scaled down in Repitier to a fairly small size - I printed it as a Star Wars Monopoly piece at .2 as well as full size and both look good... I did run it through Nettfabb Cloud repair once just to make sure the original pieces were clean. <Revised 2016> I finally found some affordable wood filament and decided this model needed to be printed in wood. In the course of doing that, I determined I wanted a little more of the missing detail (ports, marks, etc.) so I revised the model. Biggest additions are the antenna toward the back of his head. I also added some support structure to the legs which is NOT original but helps being able to print this smaller and makes it a bit more robust.. The pictures are the wood filament printed at .6 scale. It looks much better in real life than the pictures show as the closeup shows the marks and dust from cleaning up the "stringies" the wood filament seems to get more than PLA. It is an improvement I think...
Just print it without support.  10% infill works fine.  Nothing special to make it print!

I wanted to create a DXF so I could laser cut some wood / plastic drawer dividers.
I realized that rather than making a "one off" layout I could use OpenSCAD and make the dividers of any size, length, number of cells or thickness of material.

Load it up in OpenSCAD. The variables are commented in the code (and are pretty obvious). The padding values are included to allow for material / cutting variances or to just make assembly smoother. Export the compiled file in the format of choice. Other ideas to implement :

author: hamza

description.text: This provides a connector between a square-ended tube and a round-ended tube. It is an application of the superellipse http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superellipse. The script makes use of the fact that the superellipse family of curves encompassed both a square and a circle, so smooth morphing between the two can be achieved parametrically. The derivation of the script is discussed in my blog http://kitwallace.posterous.com/piet-hein-and-the-superegg

• Generation time is long for higher numbers of layers
  • Not yet proved by printing

comments.text: This is almost exactly what I need (which is actually a rectangle to round tube connector).  Thanks.  Quick question from a first time user: are the units in mm ?
comments.author: peetucket

comments.text:
units are undefined in OpenSCAD and in STL and are determined by the sofware which translates to gcode - however I always think in terms of mm.
for your connector I think this would be simpler:
eps=0.1;
module connector(h,d,w1,w2) {
hull(){
cylinder(r=d/2,h=eps);
translate([0,0,h-eps]) cube([w1,w2,eps],center=true);
}
}
module connector_tube(h,d,w1,w2,t) {
difference () {
connector (h,d,w1,w2);
translate([0,0,-eps])
connector(h + 2 * eps,d-t,w1-t,w2-t);
}
};
connector_tube(30,20,15,20,2);
comments.author: peetucket

comments.text:
This new version seems to works much better!
Ok, next step: square/rectangle-to-circle/ellipse connector! That would be great if we could choose the exact shape of input and output, but I don't know if the maths can allow that...
comments.author: fma

comments.text: Thanks - problem is that the square section becomes a lozenge rather than a rectangle when eccentricity  ne 1 - however I could go rectangle -square - ellipse but not sure it will look nice with the additional transition - working on it..

Well, this seemed like a good idea at the time, but thinking about it a bit more, a better way to achieve the same effect  would be to use hull() between a square and a circle, both extruded a tad (TAD = 0.01;)  Faster and more generic.

for a hollow duct, scale the above down a bit (only x and y) and then do the difference and you have a hollow duct. circle to square.

description.text: This is a continuation of my exploration of Tinkercad base mesh to sculptris sculpting to Tinkercad assembly. I'm pretty happy with this one. I've given up on 28mm and have upscaled this to around 58-60 to fit with the size I was happy with on the orc model. I have a game partially designed which I will flesh out for this size model and make availible once I have 6 of these figures created. The printbed file is sized to print in one batch on a replicator 1. If you are interested, base mesh is here: https://tinkercad.com/things/8Uy1HH0wbEO-archer-base-mesh Edit: The printbed sheet was throwing manifold errors. I just uploaded a new one. If you downloaded the first version, you might want to grab the repaired one.
I'm printing 2 shells, 50% infill (probably overkill) at .08mm layer height.

description.text: An easy-to-print small spool stand that works really well with different spool widths - no adjustments required, you just stick one under each side. It has built in spacers to keep the bearing free spinning along with a guardrail to keep the spool off the edges of the bearings.

Print four of these (two for each side) and assemble each side using two 16mm M3 screws, two 608 bearings (8x22x7mm) and two regular M3 nuts (I used half height nuts on mine, but full sized will work fine.)

I used replicator 2, 0.15mm layer height, support at 10% density,2 shells total, Makerware slicer (customized profile), feedrate infill at 80mm/s, travel feedrate also 80mm/s, outline (the external shell) at 50mm/s.

This is a set of Pentomino pieces in a handy carry case with swivel top. I designed it a few years ago after reading 'Chasing Vermeer' by Blue Balliett in which the main character solves a crime with the help of pentominoes. It's Nintendo DS size and a clear cover prevents the pieces from falling out. Later I made a batch of larger sets for our Maths department.
There are 2 layers of 3mm and 1 layer of 2mm acrylic. The surround of the Top layer was bonded to the Base layer with thin acrylic cement, Tensol 7. An M3 lock-nut is inserted from the very bottom and held in place by an M3 countersunk fastener that also allows the clear cover to swivel.
One of the files is in *.dtd format for direct use in UK schools where Techsoft 2D Design is widely used to laser cut.

Please refer to the screenshot of the drawing for colours vs. settings.

  • Measure the thickness of your stock material. Not all 3mm acrylics are 3mm and some shrink more than others when lasering. That's important here when matching the holes to the aluminium rod to be used as registration points for glueing and as retainers for the clear swivel cover. So measure their diameter first. For the clear cover 2mm acrylic is more elegant than 3 mm and flexes better when swivelling over the pins.

  • Measure the diameter of your pins and do a test piece to make a matching hole that is tight. The design features 2.3mm holes which you could enlarge by drilling. Change the hole diameter in the design where necessary. A tight fit is needed.

  • Set the height & apply your settings and then cut the 3 mm layers.

  • Adjust the height and cut the 2 mm clear acrylic for the cover, then countersink the larger hole carefully to match the fastener (drill press / hand countersink tool)

  • Cut the aluminium pins to size allowing them protrude about 1.5 mm, so about 4.5 in total, then file one end flat and the other domed. You could also use brass (hack some motherboard for terminals)

  • Place the surround onto the base and secure it with the aluminium pins. Insert the 3 mm lock-nut and pass the M3 countersunk fastener through the surround and screw into the lock-nut.

  • Using a fine brush or cotton butt, apply acrylic cement to the outside edges where the layers meet and let it go in between by capillary action.
    • -After a minute or so you can unscrew and then fit the clear cover. Do not overtighten your fastener. Mark how much it sticks out the bottom, remove and shorten with a hacksaw. File smooth and refit. (At this stage you should still be able to adjust or replace the aluminium pins provided they aren't glued in. They can be driven out with a nailpunch or a blunt wire nail.) Play with the Pentominoes and read the book !

description.text: A model to demonstrate and test a couple issues related to building models with the Makerbot Replicator: (1) making a sphere violates the 45 degree rule - how poorly formed is it on the bottom? (2) at 1% fill on the sphere, is skeinforge smart enough to save most of its 1% fill for the top part where it's needed? (3) with the mortise and tenon being the exact same size in Tinkercad, will the printed model actually fit together tightly? (4) can we make our own raft instead of using the Replicator G raft support option

1) It looks pretty good, actually! It's a small sphere so that helps. It's only slightly sloppy at the bottom. The facets on the sphere are legible near the top where the bottom surface is more like coiled rope.
2) For most of the model, there was almost no support inside (ie: it's hollow). The supports started showing up at the top of the sphere where they're needed (to support the cube hole)
3) The tenon was only slightly too big and needed a little bit of shaving with a knife. After that, the two pieces fit together very tightly and really would not require glue in our case
4) The raft worked fine and was easy to cut off. The model was designed so the top of the sphere was slightly flattened but the printed model is pretty spherical still. One unexpected detail is that the circular ring portion printed hollow. We used the default of 10% fill for that model and maybe that was too low to properly form the narrow part of the ring. Unexpected and a bug I would think.

This is a cover to fit the Space Navigator 3D mouse when it's not in use.
The Space Navigator 3D mouse by 3DConnexion is a great bit of kit and has a lovely bright blue LED ring in the base. What isn't so lovely is trying to get to sleep with that bright blue LED ring in the same room if you happen to have it in a bedroom and leave your PC/Mac switched on overnight.
To get around this issue I created a nice little hat for it. It also contains a little notch for the cable to go through.

This has been designed in Solidworks and I've included the original file for people to tinker with as they wish. I've printed the cover on my Rep2 at 0.2 layer height with 20% infill and 2 additional shells with great results.
You will need supports. I've tried printing it upside-down with external supports and also the correct way up with internal supports. Both work however I suggest using the internal supports because it doesn't affect the shell quality (as pictured).

description.text: These are two wall mount cradles for an RC sail boat. The bow and stern files have a different cradle profile to accommodate the shape of the hull and provide more support for the model. These cradles would work for many different boats of similar or larger size. I included the Sketchup file if you want to modify this design.

I printed in white ABS but PLA would work just as well. I used 25% infill.  I screwed to the wall using 1/8th inch toggle bolts. I used some clear tubing slit lengthwise as padding for the boat. It may be necessary to open up the holes a bit to get the bolts though. After installing I found these cradles using the toggle bolts were quite sturdy and would capable of holding a much larger boat or other object.

After trying different designs that didn't work for me, I sat down and made my own in Autodesk 123D design.
This is for the acrylic version of Mendel90, and the gap is 6,2 mm.
My printer uses 6mm acrylic sheets and fits perfectly.
The white plastic tube is 32 mm PVC, buy it in the hardware store near you.
If it's too much friction between the roll and the tube, lubricate with a candlelight on top of the PVC tube. Works like a charm, and it saves you a couple of ball bearings.
If you want to, you can use a couple of rubber "things" normally used on drawers, in the gap. I didn't have any need for that.
Cheers, hope you find it useful!

Designed in 123D Design.
Printed on Mendel90.

A large (20mm ID) segmented flex tube for sucking away chips. <del >This will eventually have a connection to a 1 7/8 shop vac hose and T-Slot mount to allow mounting to a small CNC mill/router.</del> its on hold for now, I have added a base though.  
Make Sure you print with the snap fingers down. There is a larger surface area meant to stick to the platform.  
I went through several iterations to optimize the snap features and reliability. I still have some trouble with delamination along the layer lines. This occurs more often when disconnecting two segments. Adding some CA glue on the inside face of the snap fingers helps. Printing at a setting smaller than 0.3 would probably help but I have been too impatient so far :)  
Added a Base per request. Base has a 1.25" square mounting pattern

author: tomirendo

title: Kitty Cat Head Charm Pendant Earrings or Necklace

description.text:
Here is my kitty cat head design I made over a year ago for a ring. I reused my model and made them into earrings. These will fit over 6g and 8g plugs. You could also put sterling hooks on them or even put it on a cord, to then wear around your neck.  
Great for cat lovers! You might even think it was a fox if you were into that sort of animal. ;)   
Enjoy and happy printing!

I started this sculpture in ZBrush over a year ago and recently remastered the sculpture in Meshmixer. I would suggest going nice and slow, and using the smallest layer height, in respect to your stepper motor, to get the best detail. I printed two on the bed, adjacent from each other and the print took 1hr20min~ for me. I print only in PLA and yes they made it through the drop test multiple times.  
You know, because every 3D print gets dropped at least once! =D

My son wanted a swinging target to shoot with his airsoft and BB Gun. I created this target stand and swinging targets.
It has room for 3 Targets, 2 big 1 small.
I've modified the design from the first version to include the following:
  • Cross bar has groove on the bottom to insert into side supports
    for added stability
    • thicker target hangers (1 snapped when removing it from bed)
    • Blocks on bottom of Side supports to reduce Horizontal movement

1) Print the Parts
Print out two of the "supports". I added a block on the bottom of
each to prevent horizontal movement of the stand.
Print out the "Cross Bar" with supports as you will need it because
of the rounded sections.
Print out a set of the targets. You will also need to print it with
supports.
2) Snap together the parts
Remove the support material from the targets
Snap the targets onto the cross bar
Insert the cross bar into the square holes on the supports
align the groove on the bottom of the cross bar with the supports
and press down to lock in place.

This is a small to medium sized decorative plant pot. This design uses straightforward Constructive solid geometry (CSG) of basic
solid shapes and gears. The object is 100 mm high and 100 mm in diameter and masses 144 g before painting.

Simply load the attached STL file into your 3D printer software and print. I printed it on my standard RepRapPro Mendel, using white PLA. It took about four hours.
I finished it in Bronze metallic spray paint. If you comment out the last hole, you can create a small vase.
